qas.question: What movement came into prominence in the mid-19th century that emphasized the common heritage and unity of all the Slavic peoples?
Where was the main focus of Pan-Slavism?

answers.text: the Byzantine Empire, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Venice

qas.question: Who used Pan-Slavism as a political tool?
When did the Soviet Union gain political-military influence and control over most Slavic-majority nations?
How long did the Soviet Union retain a hegemonic role?

plausible_answers.text: the Byzantine Empire, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Venice

qas.question: Who did the South Slavs rule over?
When did Venice gain power over Slavic-majority nations?
What type of role did Slavic nations play between 1989-1991?
Which area was the first to use Pan-Slavism as a political tool?
What did Austria-Hungary use pan-slavism for?

context: <a0_0>Pan-Slavism<a0_0/>, a movement which came into prominence in the mid-19th century, emphasized the common heritage and unity of all the Slavic peoples. The main focus was in the <b8_0>Balkans<b8_0/> where the South Slavs had been ruled for centuries by other empires: <a1_0><b5_0>the Byzantine Empire, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Venice<b5_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0>The Russian Empire<a2_0/> used Pan-Slavism as <b9_0>a political tool<b9_0/>; as did the Soviet Union, which gained political-military influence and control over most Slavic-majority nations <a3_0><b6_0>between 1945 and 1948<b6_0/><a3_0/> and retained a <b7_0>hegemonic<b7_0/> role <a4_0>until the period 1989–1991<a4_0/>.
